column1: Will the US civilian labor force participation rate reach or exceed 63.0% for any month in 2021?
column6: ['Business', 'Health', 'Economic Indicators', 'US Politics', 'US Policy']
Don't think the December report is going to make. This question is a one hundred percent zero.
Holiday hiring will push participation rate about 63% in late 2021
Nov - 61.8 very good!
Too much incentive to not work as a result of government stimulus. With a month to go, not going to happen in December of 2021.
It seems unlikely, but there are a lot of vacancies out there, and there is just a chance that some of those who have left the labor force might have second thoughts.
Unemployment rate is decline, while the labor force participation rate is stagnate. Thanks Biden.
Next Dec, 3, Jan, 7 61.6 for October
Stuck in the mid 61% range. I think the crowd has this one
Oct 61.6 Now looking less likely. Can’t bring myself to go to zero though.
Not happening. No one wants to work.

Still a really easy 0% chance of this as the current employment rate is 61.6% and there's no way we jump 1.4% in 3 months. We've been more or less steady since June 2020 which makes this question pretty pointless. We were only barely above 63% during the pre-pandemic boom.

Not likely, even with expected hiring surge for the holidays. "The labor force participation rate was little changed at 61.6% in September and has remained within a narrow range of 61.4% to 61.7% since June 2020. The participation rate is 1.7% points lower than in February 2020.
holding
Sept 61.6 Down from Aug. I do think there will be a pick up later in the year, but now think to enough to get to 63pc.

Next Nov. 8 61.6 in September 61.7 in August - Need 1.3 in 4 months 61.7 in July - Need 0.2 in each 3 months and 0.3 in other 2... Never happened in last 20 yrs, except Apr/Aug 2020 (+1.5) 61.6 in May and June! Not in the track.... 61.7 in April. keeping 0.2 increase monthly, will only get over 63 in Nov and Dec (63.3). Every month in pace, +10% each 0,1 +/- 10%
The past six months of data from BLS show very little change - all between 61.5 - 61.7%.
Check next release due 08/10/21

Why beat around the bush? I seen the BLS report and the trending chart (expand the link show background Information above). We are past the "point of no return", the world is what it is right now. No more wishful thinking. So I'm updating my forecast to this question 0% (zero percent).
I was once very bullish about this one, but based on data, trends, and reports. It seem like the labor force participation rate is showing no signs of recovering this year.

61.7 in August - Need 1.3 in 4 months 61.7 in July - Need 0.2 in each 3 months and 0.3 in other 2... Never happened in last 20 yrs, except Apr/Aug 2020 (+1.5) 61.6 in May and June! Not in the track.... 61.7 in April. keeping 0.2 increase monthly, will only get over 63 in Nov and Dec (63.3). Every month in pace, +10% each 0,1 +/- 10%

While participation is still unlikely to hit 63%, I think the pressures on people to participate are increasing month by month. Thanksgiving and Christmas will pull some people into the system, as will boosters.
I think it's closer to 0% than 1%.

BLS just released the monthly employment report for August. The labor force participation rate was flat at 61.7%. Wrong direction with not enough time. As a reminder, individuals on unemployment are part of this metric, per BLS definitions.
I still think there is a chance but the crowd is persuading me to cut back my expectations.

I know I out on a limb here, but I am still pretty bullish that the labor force participation rate will reach 63% at some point this year, probably around the holidays. There is just so much stimulus money circulating and with some state ending their COVID stimulus, I believe there will be an untick in the labor force participation rate. Grant it, if the Democrats pass their $3.5 trillion social programs package, that could be an additional factor in the labor force participation not reaching 63%.

Last put this out there in June that I was at 0%. We are at 61.7% as of July reporting which means we have 5 months to gain 1.3%. Other than the recovery in 2009 or the original COVID recovery, I don't see any time period dating back to 2001 where we did this successfully.
Level holding steady just under 62pc. A lot of information out there about the puzzle of why people are not rejoining the work force, as it’s not really job supply related.
This forecast is based on :

61.7 in July - Need 0.2 in 3 months and 0.3 in other 2... Never happened in last 20 yrs, except Apr/Aug 2020 (+1.5) 61.6 in May and June! Not in the track.... 61.7 in April. keeping 0.2 increase monthly, will only get over 63 in Nov and Dec (63.3). Every month in pace, +10% each 0,1 +/- 10%

Materially lowering my forecast due to the latest reading from the BLS. However, above consensus as the reports over the next few months should indicate when people want to reengage in the labor force (note: the unemployed are counted already in this metric).
-3 on passage of time. Possible we see a jump due to coronavirus unemployment insurance ending, but very unlikely it jumps that high I think.
61.4% today. Covid rising. Not likely that more people will go back to work by the end of the year.

After taking a dip in Apr 2020 at the beginning of the pandemic, the participation data has been almost flat since May 2020, ranging between 61.4 and 61.7%. Given the delta variant and the reluctance to vaccinate, it's unlikely that there will be a significant improvement in 2021. In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if even after the pandemic subsides things won't get back to pre-pandemic levels due to shifts in behavior.
Updating
With the upcoming rate of evictions, many people will lose employment due to forced relocation post eviction. The job market will continue to remain under 63% until 2022.
Lowering expectation based on my reading of other forecasters much more gloomy predictions...
It will return but probably not until 2022 given the long term global impact of Covid affecting the export economy

I tried to order pizza to-go yesterday evening. I was told that they were short-staffed and could not accept to-go orders. Five other eateries within 50 yards all had "Help Wanted" signs posted. See "The Lie of ‘No One Wants to Work" at https://www.eater.com/22417344/restaurant-labor-shortage-covid-19-unemployment-benefits-risks. For me experiencing it first hand drove home the severity of the problem.
Estimated 3% and 2% labor force increase second third and fourth quarters

Labor market is taking much longer to bounce back than many thought and unemployment benefits boost still doesn't end for another 1.5 months. Unlikely that LFP rate returns to pre-pandemic level in 2021.

Summer workers, college kids, first time employed youth, and others who are not receiving benefits are returning to employment even if not full-time employment. Subtracting retirees and disabled creates a small increase above 63%. With current value at 61.8. It would only need to go up 1.2% which is possible but hard to measure. How many 16-year-olds will be working by the end of the year? How does our new census affect? https://www.brookings.edu/research/what-the-2020-census-will-reveal-about-america-stagnating-growth-an-aging-population-and-youthful-diversity/
The trend is for labor force participation to decline as more people leave the workforce, but I expect labor force participation to increase to the stated number in the short term.

Lowering my forecast based on the BLS employment report yesterday (https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf). Yesterday's job report showed the labor force participation rate was unchanged at 61.6%.

Today's jobs report said 850,000 jobs were added in June, the strongest number since last summer and above expected. But reaching 63% would mean getting back to pre pandemic levels (January 2020 numbers) and that doesn't seem likely to happen this year.
61.6 in May and June! Not in the track.... 61.7 in April. keeping 0.2 increase monthly, will only get over 63 in Nov and Dec (63.3). Every month in pace, +10% each 0,1 +/- 10%
Time passing with little sign of an enthusiastic return to the labor force
The US labor force participation rate is calculated as: (US Civilian Labor Force over 16 years old ÷ Civilian Noninstitutional Population) x 100.
Remain bullish that as the summer comes to an end and with the number of unfilled job openings, we will see a surge in the participation rate around September.

The rate actually dropped from 61.7 to 61.6 April to May even as things were opening up, which doesn't bode well for resolving this question as a yes. I'll come down 5% and adjust again when June numbers are out.

My 8 ball says, "Don't Count on It." I give this question 2%, which does NOT favor an exceeding 63% for any month in 2021. Human nature is a complex thing, and no algorithm can measure the individual emotions of a human being. Everyone has BIAS, sadly I have bias too. That human bias will interfere with what job they want to go back to, and the same human bias will interfere with employers on who they want to hire.
The May result dropped slightly from April (from 61.7 to 61.6). I had expected further improvement, so I'm reducing my estimate.
As more people become vaccinated, I believe more people will return to work seasonal jobs. I also do not believe that numbers will return to normal yet, due to continued low wages.

The decrease in the labor force participation rate for workers overall – from 63.3% to 61.3% – exceeds that seen in the Great Recession and ranks among the largest 12-month declines in the post-World War II era, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data.
If they update the numbers it says that it would be impossible and I want to go up to percent during summer months with restaurants and tourism. https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf
May = 61.6pc
Allowing for current trends and possible figure manipulation...it seems likely

Dropping my forecast as I realize that the extended unemployment benefits don't matter. If you're on unemployment you are considered part of the labor force. So the extended unemployment benefits are not keeping people out if the labor force number.

Inverting my forecast. AARP says that 3MM seniors left the workforce early due to COVID, and it will be difficult to reach 63% participation with that much of a headwind. More optimistically, Bloomberg indicates that 'at least 1.7MM seniors retired early'... but even that smaller number will make reaching 63% difficult. https://www.aarp.org/work/working-at-50-plus/info-2021/pandemic-workers-early-retirement.html https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-03/early-retirement-surge-exacerbates-u-s-baby-boomer-inequalities#:~:text=The%20surge%20in%20early%20retirements,market%20prematurely%2C%20a%20study%20showed.

While labor force participation of 16 to 19 yo is increasing in the economic recovery, probably for the financial aspect of having a robust income immediately instead another phase of education. it's clearly the participation of women that is lagging behind and less than proportionate at the moment. Most recent figures seem to show that the gap is closing (12.2 percentage points in May 2021: 69.6% (Men, 20 years and older) vs 57.4% (Women, 20 years and older)). A return to pre-pandemic levels for women (59.2% in Feb 2020) would certainly help to come close to 63% in total civilian labor force participation, but how likely is it to happen within half a year?

some labor force exits will not return post-pandemic, eg retirements. a 1.5% jump in 7 months would be well outside of historic norms, even considering pandemic distortions it seems highly unlikely to get all the way to 63%.

Pretty much for the same reasoning given by @adam-millsap; I certainly believe we will see an increase from where we were in April but I do no believe that it will be to the degree that will push it past 63% by year end. For one, there is currently a labor shortage as the result of social preferences shifting in both younger and older populations over the past twelve months that appears unlikely to correct in a manner which would appear favorable towards labor force participation rate growth beyond this 63% threshold. Additionally, states which can hold back this rate overall such as NY and California - due to their large populations in major urban metros - appear to favor providing social assistance to residents who do not wish to return to work, which will further deter individuals from seeking employment in cases where benefits exceed minimum wage rates or salaries paid for their skill level or occupation (income levels which may potentially comprise a large swath of labor force in these areas).
Recovery increasing slowly; don't believe it will leap to 63 before the end of year despite that half of US states will end federal bonus unemployment affecting 3.7 million people.

Just looking at the chart of the BLS data, We're seeing that March 2017 was the first pop to 63% and the only sustained period at or above 63% came form July 2019-Feb 2020. That was a big time for not only the US market, but world markets were also humming along. COVID has shot all of that in the foot and there is no way the world recovers from this fast enough to get the engines running back at that speed in the next 6 months.

Since values > 63% were standard before COVID began, I'm betting that when schools resume in-person instruction a lot of parents will rejoin the work force. This may even be reached earlier when unemployment benefits are cancelled in Red States (which will happen over the summer). This could be counteracted by retiring Baby Boomers, but I am seeing many Boomers choose to continue working. https://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.t01.htm

Though I expect unemployment to decline MoM, we were barely at 63% participation rate when unemployment was down to 3%; lots of parents (mothers especially) dropped out of the workforce and are unlikely to return any time soon.

LFP rate has been trending down for decades and only above 63% a handful of months since 2014. Population is aging, boomers are retiring, and immigration is curtailed, making it unlikely that we hit an LFP rate of 63% before the end of 2021. Higher corporate taxes and other tax increases also reduce investment and labor demand, while a more generous safety net raises reservation wages. Current administration is looking to do both, which will put downward pressure on LFP rate.

This is going to be closer than recent forecasts suggest. Still less likely than even, but jobs numbers for the last few months have been promising. Most shocks are going to slow down the labor force recovery, so significant downside. Lots of ways to fall off the trend which puts us above 63.0.

There are a lot of factors at work here that could result in the rate going either way in the next seven months. A major factor is inflation. We are already seeing inflation ticking up as a result of over stimulation of state and federal cash transfers and spending. As a result, there is a lot of pent up money out there without anything to purchase and supply restraints. One of two things could happen. That pent up money begins flooding the market, resulting in companies increasing hiring to meet demand resulting in more stimulation and inflation, but would probably increase the participation rate over 63%. Or the federal government attempts to intervene to control inflation, which, depending one which mechanism they employ, could result in the participation rate either increasing or decreasing. One possibility is the increase of federal cash transfers/benefits makes it more advantageous to not enter the workforce in the short term. Additionally, the federal debt to GDP is over 133%. Generally, anything over 80% is not considered financially stable, which historically has led to increased printing of money then inflation and if not controlled hyperinflation. Currently such notable countries as Sudan (212%), Eretria (176%), Suriname (166%), Barbados (143%), Maldives (140%), Cape Verde (138%), and Belize (127%) top the list of countries with the highest debt to GPD rate. Of note, also among the top ten are Japan (257%), Greece (210%), and Italy (157%), all of which have faced limited adverse economic impact, mainly slow growth, in comparation to the other countries on the top ten list. Japan, for almost a decade now, has aggressively pursued an economic policy of high government spending in exchange for controlled, slow economic growth. Italy is pursuing a similar policy. So, what does all of this mean? The federal government better have a plan in place that does not solely relay on economic growth or even an economic boom. I am not not that confident in the ability of the federal government, which leads me to believe that it is more than likely a 63% or higher participation rate will be hit this year, but what comes next could be very messy. Of note, the participate rate has never recovered from the Great Recession, but that is a discussion for another day.
The US civillian labor force participation rate is the mirror image of another BLS figure, "Persons not in the labor force who want a job"
61.7 in April. keeping 0.2 increase monthly, will only get over 63 in Nov and Dec (63.3). Every month in pace, +10% each 0,1 +/- 10%
https://www.bls.gov/charts/employment-situation/civilian-labor-force-participation-rate.htm

Labor force participation has been trending down as the boomers age. Save the unsustainable low unemployment during the last few years, we shouldn't have seen the level over 63%. I suspect the participation rate will stay under 63% unless we see a massive shock to the system.

I expect the labor participation rate to approach its pre-pandemic level above 63% by the end of the year. - The extended unemployment benefits will expire in September (and sooner in some red states). - There will be pent-up demand from consumers, so businesses will hire more employees to meet the demand. - Some people are still waiting until all COVID restrictions are lifted (which will happen in CA on June 15) and/or until they are vaccinated to look for work.

Raising my forecast based on expiring unemployment benefits. This is not in a majority of States though and it's not in the big ones like California or New York. Texas is the largest. https://www.zerohedge.com/economics/less-two-weeks-millions-americans-set-lose-unemployment-benefits

I don't see how that could happen, labor force participation had been dropping and had only risen above 63% in 2019 after years of falling or holding steady. The unemployment rate in 2019 was around 3.6%, while the FED and others are expecting unemployment in the high 4% range at the end of this year. We have an aging population so labor force participation is probably not going to start doing unusually high numbers. Seems very unlikely, and the only reason I'm giving 20% is because the pandemic is weird.

https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CIVPART While much higher labor force participation rates have been seen historically, it has struggled to stay above 63% since about 2014. Also, it does not appear to be the kind of statistic that moves quickly (outside of major upheavals). Zooming out on the chart, there is not a single instance of a 1.5% jump in participation rate within a ~7 month period of time. There was a single period of time that was very close, however: 58.1% in Dec 1954 to 59.7% in Aug 1955. Obviously COVID is a special case -- this is also the most rapid decrease in participation rate ever seen. The loss of businesses and the additional unemployment benefits (though these may end before the end of the year) will be a damper though.
New Economic activity requires some time to get established during times of disruption.

"Job losses in the pandemic have been concentrated in service sectors in which women account for the majority of employment, such as leisure and hospitality and education and health services" ie. The participation rate will hinge heavily on convincing people its safe to travel and recreate. That said, the rate pre-pandemic was 63.4% and there's a real risk there just aren't that many looking to re-join the workforce in the near term. Long term the rate has also been dropping fairly consistently since the late 90's and with an aging population is likely to continue. With these factors working against it seems unlikely to recover to that point in the near term, if ever.
61.5 https://www.bls.gov/charts/employment-situation/civilian-labor-force-participation-rate.htm

Inflation is going to jump up more with the May posting. That will affect interest rates which will affect everything. The government's response will be to continue handing out money, which will continue to incentivize people not to work. I'm oversimplifying this of course.

"Employment in February 2021 was 8.5 million less than in February 2020, a loss that could take more than 3 years to recoup assuming job creation proceeds at roughly the same monthly rate as it did from 2018 to 2019. But a faster recovery is possible if the job gains seen in March 2021 are sustained in the coming months." (Pew Research) "For women, the labor force participation rate in February 2021 was 55.9%, compared with 57.9% a year earlier. For men, the rate fell from 69.0% to 67.1% over the same period. The decrease in the labor force participation rate for workers overall – from 63.3% to 61.3%" A lot of jobs are expected to be created over the summer as the country continues to reopen but it's likely most of those jobs will be temporary or part time. Inflation is increasing, a key indicator was up 3.1% in April as price pressures built in a rapidly expanding economy. Consumer Price Index went up 4.2% while personal income declined 13.1%. Add to that supply chain disruptions and getting back to February 2020 levels seems to take longer than the remaining 6 months of the year.

The economy will come roaring back given all the activity generated by the Biden spending. If participation was 61.5% near the bottom and it was over 63% in February 2020, I think the recovery will draw enough people back into the economy.
